intro: Ochlopoa speluncarum, commonly known as the cave morning glory, is a rare flowering plant native to the limestone caves of southeastern Brazil. It is characterized by its small, delicate flowers that bloom in the early morning, adapting to the low-light conditions of its subterranean habitat. The plant has a unique morphology, with tendrils that help it climb and anchor itself to cave walls. Its roots are specialized to absorb moisture from the damp cave environment, and it relies on a specific pollinator, the cave-dwelling bee, for reproduction. Due to its restricted habitat and sensitivity to environmental changes, Ochlopoa speluncarum is considered endangered.
